summary: Lifts over an interval list from one reference build to another.

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: Chain file that guides the LiftOver process.
arguments.name: --CHAIN

arguments.summary: Compression level for all compressed files created (e.g. BAM and VCF).
arguments.name: --COMPRESSION_LEVEL

arguments.summary: Whether to create an index when writing VCF or coordinate sorted BAM output.
arguments.name: --CREATE_INDEX

arguments.summary: Whether to create an MD5 digest for any BAM or FASTQ files created.
arguments.name: --CREATE_MD5_FILE

arguments.summary: Google Genomics API client_secrets.json file path.
arguments.name: --GA4GH_CLIENT_SECRETS

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: The input interval list to be lifted over.
arguments.name: --INPUT

arguments.summary: When writing files that need to be sorted, this will specify the number of records stored in RAM before spilling to disk. Increasing this number reduces the number of file handles needed to sort the file, and increases the amount of RAM needed.
arguments.name: --MAX_RECORDS_IN_RAM

arguments.summary: Minimum percentage of bases in each input interval that must map to output interval for liftover of that interval to occur. If the program fails to find a good target for an interval, a warning will be emitted and the interval will be dropped from the output.
arguments.name: --MIN_LIFTOVER_PCT

arguments.summary: The output interval list file.
arguments.name: --OUTPUT

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: Reference sequence file.
arguments.name: --REFERENCE_SEQUENCE

arguments.summary: Interval List file for intervals that were rejected
arguments.name: --REJECT

arguments.summary: Sequence dictionary to place in the output interval list. (This should be any file from which the dictionary of the target reference can be extracted.)
arguments.name: --SEQUENCE_DICTIONARY

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: One or more directories with space available to be used by this program for temporary storage of working files
arguments.name: --TMP_DIR

arguments.summary: Use the JDK Deflater instead of the Intel Deflater for writing compressed output
arguments.name: --USE_JDK_DEFLATER

arguments.summary: Use the JDK Inflater instead of the Intel Inflater for reading compressed input
arguments.name: --USE_JDK_INFLATER

arguments.summary: Validation stringency for all SAM files read by this program.  Setting stringency to SILENT can improve performance when processing a BAM file in which variable-length data (read, qualities, tags) do not otherwise need to be decoded.
arguments.name: --VALIDATION_STRINGENCY

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --VERBOSITY

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

description:
This tool adjusts the coordinates in an interval list on one reference to its homologous interval list on another reference, based on a chain file that describes the correspondence between the two references. It is based on the UCSC LiftOver tool and uses a UCSC chain file to guide its operation. It accepts a Picard interval_list file as an input. See IntervalListTools documentation for information on interval_list format. Note: for lifting over VCF files use LiftoverVcf tool.

Usage example:

 java -jar picard.jar LiftOverIntervalList \
       I=input.interval_list \
       O=output.interval_list \
       SD=reference_sequence.dict \
       CHAIN=build.chain

Return codes

If all the intervals lifted over successfully, program will return 0. It will return 1 otherwise.

Caveats

An interval is "lifted" in its entirety, but it might intersect (a "hit") with multiple chain-blocks. Instead of placing the interval in multiple hits, it is lifted over using the first hit that passes the threshold of #MIN_LIFTOVER_PCT. For large enough #MIN_LIFTOVER_PCT this is non-ambiguous, but if one uses small values of #MIN_LIFTOVER_PCT (perhaps in order to increase the rate of successful hits...) the liftover could end up going to the smaller of two good hits. On the other hand, if none of the hits pass the threshold a warning will be emitted and the interval will not be lifted.
name: LiftOverIntervalList (Picard)
